Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of the catalytic evaluation system for the DRM. Note: MFC = Mass flow controller; P = Pressure gage; GC = Gas chormatograph. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of (a) CeO2-S, (b) Ni/CeO2-S, (c) CeO2-B, (d) Ni/CeO2-B, (e) CeO2-D, (f) Ni/CeO2-D, (g) CeO2-C and (h) Ni/CeO2-C. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns:(a) CeO2,(b) Ni/CeO2 and (c) Enlarged view of Fig. 3(b). Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and (b) pore size distribution of the calcined Ni/CeO2 samples. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Ce 3d, (b) O 1 s, (c) Ni 2p XPS spectra of the Ni/CeO2 samples and (d) the relationship between XPS results & catalytic activity (Reaction conditions: 800 °C, CO2/CH4 = 1, 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1) . Fig 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles of the samples: (a) CeO2 and (b) Ni/CeO2. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) CO2-TPD profiles and (b) Raman spectra of the reduced Ni/CeO2. Fig 7 Fig. 8 TEM images of reduced (a) Ni/CeO2-D, (b) Ni/CeO2-B, (c) Ni/CeO2-S, (d) Ni/CeO2-C and spent (e) & (i) Ni/CeO2-D, (f) & (j) Ni/CeO2-B, (g) & (k) Ni/CeO2-S, (h) & (l) Ni/CeO2-C. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (a) XRD patterns and (b) TG of spent Ni/CeO2 samples after 6 h reaction. Fig 9 Fig. 10 (a) CH4 conversion, (b) CO2 conversion and (c) H2/CO for 6 h (Reaction conditions: 800 °C, GHSV = 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1, CH4:CO2 = 1). (d) Arrhenius plots in terms of CH4 conversion rate in DRM over Ni/CeO2. Fig 10 Fig. 11 (a) The effect of temperature on the catalytic activity. Reaction conditions: CO2/CH4=1; GHSV = 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1; (b) The effect of WHSV on the catalytic activity. Reaction conditions: T = 800 °C;CO2/CH4 = 1. Fig 11 Fig. 12 The catalytic activity of Ni/CeO2-D in DRM for 30 h. Reaction conditions: 800 °C;CO2/CH4 = 1; GHSV = 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat−1. Morphology effect of ceria support with hierarchical structure on the catalytic performance for nickel-based catalysts in dry reforming of methane Shuqin Gao Conceptualization Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Methodology a b Yanan Li Methodology a b Wenzhao Guo Data curation a b Xin Ding Resources a Lan Zheng Visualization a Le Wu Software a Hongli Yan Resources c Yuqi Wang Methodology Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources a b ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi'an 710069, China School of Chemical Engineering Northwest University Xi'an 710069 China aSchool of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi'an 710069, China b Shaanxi Key Laboratory for Carbon Neutral Technology, Xi'an 710069, China Shaanxi Key Laboratory for Carbon Neutral Technology Xi'an 710069 China bShaanxi Key Laboratory for Carbon Neutral Technology, Xi'an 710069, China c Department of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University City College, Xi'an, 710018, China Department of Mechanical Engineering Xi'an Jiaotong University City College Xi'an 710018 China cDepartment of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University City College, Xi'an, 710018, China ⁎ Corresponding author. CeO2 is widely used as Ni-based catalyst support in methane dry reforming (DRM), and the hierarchical structure of the ceria behaves a favorable effect on the performance of the catalyst. Ceria with different morphologies, including dumbbell (CeO2-D), bouquet (CeO2-B) and shuttle (CeO2-S) shapes, are hydrothermally prepared, and the effect of ceria shape on the catalytic performance of Ni/CeO2 in DRM is investigated by a fixed-bed tubular reactor. The results indicate that Ni/CeO2-D demonstrates the best reaction conversions & TOF value, whose conversions of CH4 & CO2 can reach 92% & 87%, respectively. Furthermore, a series of characterization results (XPS, H2-TPR and Raman) confirm that the Ni/CeO2-D own the abundant oxygen vacancies and strong metal-support interaction, which promote the reactivity of CH4 and CO2, resulting in its most prominent catalytic performance. Additionally, Ni/CeO2-D possesses other distinct advantages due to its hierarchical dumbbell-like structure confirmed by high Ni dispersion (H2-TPD), abundant surface oxygen (H2-TPR) and sufficient basic sites (CO2-TPD). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ceria supports Ni/CeO2 catalysts Dry reforming of methane Surface oxygen vacancies Strong metal-support interaction Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM) can convert methane and carbon dioxide Eq. (1)) into syngas [1,2], which uses two of the world's most abundant greenhouse gasses as feedstock to produce high-value chemicals, offering an effective strategy to address climate issues [3,4]. Since the H2/CO ratio produced by this chemical process of DRM is unity, it can facilitate the synthesis of high hydrocarbons via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [5]. Due to the inertness of the reactants, highly endothermic DRM reaction generally require higher operating temperature (900–1273 K) to achieve its desired conversion levels [6]. Meanwhile the nickel-based catalysts are widely employed in DRM reaction for their high catalytic activity and low cost features [3], which could suffer severe carbon deposition and deactivation owing to the occurrence of some thermodynamically favorable side reactions (Eqs. (2) and ((3)) under high operating temperatures [7]. In the past few decades, numerous scholars have devoted to promoting the catalytic activity and inhibiting the catalyst deactivation caused by the side reactions Eqs. (2)–((4)) [8]. Qu et al. [9] concluded that the oxygen vacancies of the catalysts act as a key role in the enhancement of CO2 activation and catalytic performance. Liu et al. [10] reported that the strong metal-support interactions can advance the methane dissociation in the active metal phase, and generate the CH x and CO x species subsequently. DRM reaction and other side reactions are shown as follow: DRM reaction: (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 K = 247 kJ / mol reverse water gas shift reaction: (2) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 K = 41 kJ / mol methane decomposition: (3) C H 4 ↔ 2 H 2 + C Δ H 298 K = 75 kJ / mol boudouard reaction: (4) 2 CO ↔ C O 2 + C Δ H 298 K = − 173 kJ / mol More importantly, the support plays a pivotal role in enhancing the catalytic activity, which may significantly affect the physicochemical properties, surface oxygen vacancies, and interaction between active metal & support of the catalysts. For some inert supports such as SiO2 [11], both reactants are activated at the active metal sites. Once the side reactions generate the coke, the subsequent carbon dioxide activation tends to be restrained, resulting in the rapid deactivation of Ni-based catalyst. Therefore, some metal oxides with Lewis basicity such as La2O3 [12], MgO [13], and CeO2 [6] have attracted a lot of attentions since CH4 & CO2 can be activated at the metal sites and on the above mentioned supports, respectively, exhibiting a bifunctional mechanism in DRM reaction. Compared with other supports, CeO2 stands out due to its unique chemical and physical properties [14]. As ceria exists in both Ce3+ and Ce4+, the reversible valence state change of Ce4+/Ce3+ would lead to its good redox properties and abundant structural defects (oxygen vacancies) [15], which can also improve the lattice oxygen mobility, active oxygen amount [16] and oxygen storage capacity required in the reaction process [17]. Generally, the type of support also affects the catalytic performance through the interaction between the active metal and support [18], and ceria is proved to be an oxide support that easily interacts with active metal phases [19]. Simultaneously, recent studies [20,21] have illustrated that tuning the surface structure and morphology of ceria may largely alter its physicochemical properties. Zhang et al. [22] confirmed the CeO2 morphology can effectively tune the reactivity of oxygen species to satisfy the requirements of different type catalytic oxidation reactions. Rood et al. [23] synthesized ceria nanoflakes that can confine the aggregation and uniform the particle size distribution of active metals, exhibiting excellent anti-sintering ability for CO oxidation and DRM reactions. To elevate the catalytic ability of the prepared samples, a lot of investigations have been conducted on the morphology-controlled of CeO2 synthesis, especially focusing on enhancing the surface oxygen vacancies, the number of reactive oxygen species, and its interaction with active metals. For most of the previous studies, many scholars prepared the ceria with traditional structures, such as nanofibers [24], nanorods [25], and nanoparticles [26]. However, the ceria with the expected 3D hierarchical structure is rarely explored as a nickel-based catalyst support in DRM, and 3D hierarchical ceria behaves an outstanding properties than those supports with traditional 1D/2D structure [27]. Although some researchers successfully prepared the three-dimensionally structured CeO2 [28], few report can be found using the hierarchical structures of ceria in DRM reaction. In addition, most previous hierarchical materials were produced with expensive templates [29], which require complicated synthesis steps and could hardly be removed completely, leading to the undesirable impurities doping inside the carries and partial loss of catalytic activity. In this work, we employed a facile and flexible template-free hydrothermal method to synthesize CeO2 supports including the dumbbell-like, bouquet-like and shuttle-like structures, which were further studied and compared with commercial CeO2. Simultaneously, the ceria with different morphologies was used as supports for nickel-based catalysts in DRM reaction, revealing its structure-activity relationship accordingly. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Urea, alcohol, dihydrate trisodium citrate (C6H5Na3O7·2H2O), commercial CeO2, cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) were analytical grade and used without further purification before the synthesized process. All of the above original materials were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of Ni/CeO2 catalysts The preparation of the Ni/CeO2 catalysts consists of two steps: synthesis of the CeO2 supports and Ni impregnation on the synthesized carriers. The CeO2 with characteristic morphologies was produced by a simple template-free hydrothermal method, and their preparation steps were similar. However the raw materials and hydrothermal conditions for the synthesis of catalyst samples had a few discrepancies, which were listed in Table 1 . For catalysts preparation, the raw materials were firstly dissolved in deionized water at the appropriate molar ratio, followed by stirring for 30 min and sonication for 1 h. Next this mixture was transferred to a 100 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave for hydrothermal treatment under the designated temperature and reaction time. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the precipitant could be obtained via the filtration and several times water wash. Then the filtered samples were dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h (10 °C/min ramp rate) . Ni/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by ultrasound-assisted impregnation method. The proper amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in water, afterwards 2 g of CeO2 was added into the solution, and this mixture was stirred for 1 h and sonicated for 1 h under room temperature. Next the samples were dried at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 800 °C for 6 h. Meanwhile the Ni/CeO2 samples were labeled as Ni/CeO2-C (Commercial CeO2), Ni/CeO2-S (Shuttle-like CeO2), Ni/CeO2-B (Bouquet-like CeO2) and Ni/CeO2-D (Dumbbell-like CeO2), respectively, and nickel loading was maintained at a fixed proportion of 10 wt%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the calcined catalysts was carried out using a Smart LAB SE diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation source at 40 kV and 40 mA (λ = 1.5418 Å). The XRD analysis ranged from 15° to 90° with a scan rate of 10°/min and a step size of 0.02°, and the average grain sizes of the samples were calculated by the Scherrer equation. The N2 adsorption-desorption experiment was conducted on Micromeritics ASAP 2469 at 77 K. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the calcined catalysts were acquired using the standard Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Brunauer-Joyner-Hallenda (BJH) methods. The morphology of the fresh samples was observed by a Zeiss Sigma300 scanning electron microscope (SEM). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was detected on a Thermo-ESCALAB 250XI spectrometer, and the carbonaceous C 1s line (284.6 eV) was used as the reference to calibrate the binding energies (BEs). H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem II-2920. For the TPR analysis, 0.1 g of the fresh sample was pretreated in a He flow at 400 °C for 1 h. After cooling it to 50 °C, H2 flow at 30 ml/min was passed through the catalyst bed and the temperature was raised to 900 °C (10 °C/min). The CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurement was also performed on the Micromeritics AutoChem II-2920. Firstly the reduced samples were pretreated in a 40 mL/min He flow at 400 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to 50 °C in the same flow. Afterwards, the samples were exposed to a CO2 flow of 40 mL/min for 60 min, and then purged with a He flow of 40 mL/min. Eventually, the desorption dates were recorded when the samples were heated from 50 to 900 °C (10 °C/min). The H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) used the same experimental apparatus and procedure as the CO2-TPD experiment, except that CO2 was replaced by H2. The calculation equations for Ni dispersion and the turnover frequency (TOF) value of CH4 based on the H2-TPD were given in supporting information. Raman spectra were recorded on a Raman spectrometer (LabRAM HR Evolution; Horiba Scientific) with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm and the laser power of 5 mW. The morphologies of the reduced and spent catalysts were characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL-JEM 2100Plus) at an operating voltage of 200 kV. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performances of the samples were evaluated under atmospheric pressure in a quartz tubular reactor with 10 mm inner diameter. Fig. 1 depicted the schematic diagram of the catalytic evaluation system. The prepared catalyst of 0.25 g (20–40 mesh) was diluted with 0.25 g quartz sand (40–60 mesh) placed on quartz wool. Prior to the activity test, the catalyst was reduced in a mixed gasses ambience of H2 (10 mL/min) & N2 (20 mL/min) at 700 °C for 60 min. Next the reaction temperature was controlled at 800 °C (ramp rate 10 °C/min), and the gaseous mixture of CH4 (35 mL/min), CO2 (35 mL/min) and N2 (20 mL/min) was introduced. A cold trap was located between the tubular reactor outlet and the GC injection port to remove the water in the resultant gasses after DRM reaction. The gas products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC2060, Shanghai Ruimin Instrument Co., Ltd.) equipped with 5A molecular sieve & TDX-1 (Ar as the carrier gas), and the experimental data were recorded every 30 mins during the catalytic performance evaluation tests. The CH4 and CO2 conversions (XCH4 and XCO2 ), yields of H2 & CO (YH2 and YCO ) and H2/CO ratio in the DRM reaction could be calculated by the following equations: (5) X C H 4 = [ C H 4 ] i n − [ C H 4 ] o u t [ C H 4 ] i n (6) X C O 2 = [ C O 2 ] i n − [ C O 2 ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n (7) Y H 2 = [ H 2 ] o u t 2 × [ C H 4 ] i n (8) Y C O = [ C O ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n + [ C H 4 ] i n (9) H 2 C O = [ H 2 ] o u t [ C O ] o u t 3 Result and discussion 3.1 SEM The morphology of the prepared CeO2 supports and the corresponding Ni/CeO2 catalysts were investigated by SEM. It can be seen that the samples with various shapes were successfully prepared by the hydrothermal method (Fig. 2 ), and the different morphologies were uniform and single (Fig. S1). In Fig 2a, the shuttle-like CeO2 was synthesized at 120 °C by 8 h hydrothermal reaction using urea as precipitant. On the basis of this preparation method, the bouquet-like CeO2 (Fig. 2c) was produced by extra adding of C6H5Na3O7·2H2O as the morphology control agent [31], and the hydrothermal temperature remained unchanged but the reaction time was extended to 48 h. Moreover, the prepared bouquet-like CeO2 was composed of lots of nanorods with a length of about 2.7 μm and an average diameter of 150 nm, which were connected at one end and diverge at the other end to form the bouquet-like hierarchical structure. In Fig. 2e, the dumbbell-like ceria comprised of many tapered nanorods with around 2.8 μm in lengths can be prepared by adding the absolute ethanol, and the hydrothermal reaction temperature and time were controlled at 90 °C & 12 h, respectively. The proposed formation mechanism of dumbbell-shaped CeO2 with hierarchical nanorods might be the combination of an Ostwald ripening process and oriented attachment [32]. In the hydrothermal reaction, water molecules were preferentially combined with alcohol molecules and the hydrothermally obtained ceria nanocrystals slowly growed into rods until Ostwald ripening finished. Meanwhile, alcohol molecules may be adsorbed on the surface of ceria nanocrystals, reducing the crystal growth rate and inducing the nanoparticles to form the dumbbell shape when the oriented attachment process was dominant. It is also reported [32] that the emergence of the tapered ends of CeO2 nanocrystals and the gradual aggregation of tapered nanorods to evolve into 3D dumbbell-like hierarchies can correspondingly achieve lower surface energies. Comparatively, from Fig. 2g we can discover that the amorphous cerium oxide (commercial powder) had relatively smooth surface and less pore structure, leading to the unfavorable immobilization and facile agglomeration of active metals when used as a catalyst support. The SEM images of Ni/CeO2-S, Ni/CeO2-B, Ni/CeO2-D and Ni/CeO2-C catalysts were shown in Fig. 2b, d, f and h, respectively. After impregnated with 10 wt% nickel, three different morphologies of ceria fundamentally maintained their original crystal shapes. The morphology of Ni/CeO2-B varied evidently, which consisted of nanorods before changed to nanospheres with an average diameter of 128 nm. Simultaneously, the surface agglomeration and block accumulation occurred for the Ni/CeO2-C sample. Furthermore, according to the Mapping diagram of each element of the Ni/CeO2 samples (Fig. S2), the nickel species were uniformly dispersed on the carrier surface as expected. 3.2 XRD The XRD measurements of CeO2 supports and Ni/CeO2 catalysts after calcination were conducted and the results were depicted in Fig. 3 . From the figure we can see that all samples had diffraction peaks at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7° and 79.1°, which attributed to pure cerium oxide with cubic fluorite structure, corresponding to the crystal planes (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), respectively [33]. Moreover, no other crystalline byproduct was observed in Fig. 3a, indicating that the calcination can fully convert the hydrothermal precipitates into high-purity CeO2 crystals [34]. In Fig. 3b, several weak diffraction peaks appeared at 37.3°, 43.4°, and 63.0° after the metal nickel was impregnated on the surface of ceria, which could be ascribed to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes for the NiO cubic phase, respectively [35]. The average crystallite size of NiO phase was calculated by the Scherrer equation (Table 2 ). It was evident that the mean grain size of NiO largely depends on the morphology of CeO2 carrier, as the shape of ceria may lead to differences in the metal-support interaction and thus affect the nickel particle size. Meanwhile, the Ni/CeO2-D sample owned the smallest average crystallite size of the NiO phase among all the prepared catalysts. Correspondingly, the magnified image (Fig. 3c) also displayed the weaker and broader NiO diffraction peaks, which may be due to its strong interaction between NiO & CeO2-D that could suppress the agglomeration & growth of NiO, resulting in the smallest Ni particle size [36,37]. Moreover, XRD measurements for the reduced Ni/CeO2 catalysts were conducted, and the results were shown in Fig. S3. Compared with the fresh catalysts, the nickel species of the reduced catalysts existed in the form of metal Ni instead of NiO, and the diffraction peaks of active Ni appeared at 44.5° and 51.9° as expected. Importantly, the diffraction peak corresponding to Ni for Ni/CeO2-D was extremely weak and wide, owing to its small size and uniform dispersion of Ni particles in the dumbbell shaped CeO2 [5]. Simultaneously, the grain size of Ni was calculated using the Scherrer equation (Table S1), and Ni/CeO2-D had the least Ni particle size (20 nm), further verifying its favorable Ni dispersity and catalytic performance. 3.3 BET To investigate the physical properties of the catalyst samples, the N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted and the results were depicted in Fig. 4 . From Fig. 4a we can find the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the synthesized catalysts, which exhibited notable differences in the pore structure when the CeO2 supports had different morphologies. All the prepared catalysts presented IV type isotherms generally derived from mesoporous-type adsorbent materials [38]. Meanwhile, Ni/CeO2-D and Ni/CeO2-S were H2-type hysteresis loop, while Ni/CeO2-B and Ni/CeO2-C displayed H3-type hysteresis loop. According to IUPAC, H2-type hysteresis loop could normally be generated by the porous sorbent or homogeneous particle accumulation pores, indicating the formation of regular mesoporous structure inside the prepared catalysts [39]. Moreover, the presence of H3-type hysteresis loop at higher relative pressures (p/p0>0.6), which might generally be produced by mesoporous or macroporous materials with large and diffuse slit-like pores [40], illustrating its irregular pore structure and wide pore size distribution [41]. Among all the catalysts, Ni/CeO2-D displayed an outstanding hysteresis loop, suggesting that the dumbbell-shaped CeO2 as support can facilitate the formation of mesopores and abundant pores [42]. In Fig. 4b, the pore size distributions for Ni/CeO2-D and Ni/CeO2-S were largely located within the mesoporous range, while the Ni/CeO2-C sample displayed apparently wide pore size distribution and low mesoporosity. The mesopores can not only offer a large adsorption space for the reaction gasses, but also better confine the nickel metal particles within the support, thereby enhancing the metal-support interaction [34]. Additionally, Ni/CeO2-B sample showed a weak adsorption amount, corresponding to an undeveloped pore structure and pore size distribution accordingly. Table 2 summarized a few textural properties of the catalyst samples including specific surface area, pore volume and pore size. It can be revealed from the table that the average pore size of Ni/CeO2 sample was inversely proportional to its specific surface area and pore volume. It is worth noting that Ni/CeO2-D had the largest specific surface area & pore volume, well-developed pore structure and uniform mesopores, and thus performed a positive effect on the catalytic activity [43]. 3.4 XPS To explore the effect of ceria morphology on the surface chemical state of Ni/CeO2 catalysts, the XPS spectra of Ce 3d, O 1 s and Ni 2p of the prepared samples were analyzed, and the results were shown in Fig. 5 and Table 3 . In Fig. 5a, the Ce 3d XPS spectra of all samples can be divided into eight characteristic peaks [44], and the four characteristic peaks at 882.1 eV, 884.4 eV, 888.8 eV and 898.2 eV for the Ce 3d5/2 spin-orbit component were marked as: v, v´, v´´ and v´´´, respectively. Meanwhile, the rest four peaks at 900.6 eV, 903.2 eV, 907.7 eV and 916.8 eV belonged to the Ce 3d3/2 spin-orbit component, which could be represented as u, u´, u´´, and u´´´, respectively. Among the eight peaks, the v´ and u´ peaks with the initial electronic state of 3d10 4f1 could be attributed to the Ce3+ species [45], and the remaining six peaks were corresponded to the Ce4+ species, indicating that Ce3+ and Ce4+ coexisted on the surface of Ni/CeO2 with reversible redox cycle. This reversible valence state change endowed the catalysts with good redox performance & oxygen storage capacity, and the lattice oxygen inside the CeO2 would escape from the structure and generate intrinsic oxygen vacancies [27], thereby promoting the adsorption & activation of CO2 and improving the catalytic activity of catalysts [46]. Moreover, the Ce3+ concentration on the sample surface can be calculated by Eq. (10), which maintained a close connection with its surface oxygen vacancies [47], and Ni/CeO2-D possessed the highest Ce3+ concentration of 19.55%, followed by Ni/CeO2-B (17.23%), Ni/CeO2-S (16.39%) and Ni/CeO2-C (only 15.04%) (10) [ C e 3 + ] = peak area ( v , u ) total peak area In Fig. 5b, the O 1 s XPS spectrum could be classified into three peaks, labeled as Oα, Oβ and Oγ, respectively [48]. The peak at low binding energy (∼529.4 eV) could be attributed to lattice oxygen (Oα) with high oxidation state [47]. Meanwhile, the Oβ peak appeared at higher binding energy (531.4 eV) indicated the presence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which might act as the similar effect of surface active oxygen as desired. The lowest peak (Oγ) centered at 533.0 eV might be ascribed to the chemisorbed oxygen including the adsorbed water, hydroxyl radicals and -CO3 on the catalysts surface. Table 3 showed that the calculated percentages of the oxygen vacancies are 30.11%, 26.52%, 25.56%, and 20.32%, corresponding to Ni/CeO2-D, Ni/CeO2-B, Ni/CeO2-S and Ni/CeO2-C. It can be clearly seen that the Ni/CeO2-D sample owned the largest amount of oxygen vacancies, whereas Ni/CeO2-C exhibited the poorest DRM catalytic performance with the lowest oxygen vacancies content. During the DRM reaction, the adsorption and dissociation of CO2 can occur on the surface oxygen vacancies and generate CO and oxygen species subsequently, suggesting the high surface oxygen vacancies concentration can evidently promote the catalytic activity. Moreover, the Oα binding energy of Ni/CeO2-D was the highest among all the samples, which may be attributed to its NiOCe structure with strong Ni-CeO2 interaction. Meanwhile, the NiOCe structure of Ni/CeO2-D could weaken the adjacent CeO bond and excite the lattice oxygen involved in CeO2 [22], and thus contributed its higher Oα binding energy as desired. The oxidative state of nickel species on the sample surface was studied according to the Ni 2p3/2 spectra. As depicted in Fig. 5c, the peak at around 854–855 eV was attributed to the NiO dispersed on the surface of the sample, and the binding energy shifted to a higher position compared with pure NiO (853.6 eV) [40], indicating the presence of weak or moderate metal-support interaction. The peaks located at higher bond energies represented nickel species that could interact strongly with the CeO2 support [49], which was largely because that Ni2+ could enter the ceria lattice with substitution for bulk Ce4+ or with location at interstitial sites and formed Ni-O-Ce phase [22]. It can be observed that both NiO and Ni-O-Ce phase appeared their corresponding peaks with different peak areas in all samples, and the peak area ratio (areaNi-O-Ce / areaNiO) for different samples obeyed the following order: Ni/CeO2-D (1.78) > Ni/CeO2-B (1.64) > Ni/CeO2-S (1.56) > Ni/CeO2-C (1.36). Importantly, the largest ratio of Ni/CeO2-D (1.78) confirmed the existence of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [22], which can change the electronic properties of metal and the adsorption properties of reactants, resulting in a desirable promotion for methane adsorption/dissociation [10,50]. Therefore, the SMSI present in the Ni/CeO2-D sample favored the generation of CH x and further reaction with reactive oxygen species to generate CO and H2, thereby improving the catalytic activity as expected . In Fig. 5(d), the catalytic activity of different samples showed a positive correlation with oxygen vacancies and Ni-O-Ce phase content, which was consistent with the previous reports [50,51]. Additionally, XPS analysis on the reduced samples was carried out and the results were depicted in Fig.S4. It can be revealed from figure that the Ni 2p3/2 spectra for reduced samples could be decomposed into two peaks, corresponding to the Ni0 and Ni2+ species at ∼852.7 eV and ∼855.6 eV, respectively [52]. Notably, Ni/CeO2-D owned the largest proportion of Ni0 peak, which was consistent with our conclusion that Ni/CeO2-D had the smallest particle size (XRD results) and highest dispersity of metal Ni (H2-TPD results) . Furthermore, for the reduced samples, Ni/CeO2-D still possessed the highest concentration of Ce3+ (24%) and oxygen vacancies (44%) as expected. 3.5 TPR The H2-TPR experiment was measured in order to investigate the redox property for the prepared samples and the experimental results were summarized in Fig. 6 and Tables 4 , 5 . From Fig. 6a we can find that the bare ceria support mainly consumes hydrogen in three temperature ranges: < 350 °C, 350–570 °C and > 570 °C, corresponding to the reduction process of surface oxygen (Os1), subsurface oxygen (Os2) and bulk oxygen (Ob) [53]. Amongst them, the Os1 peak is deemed to be related to the surface oxygen vacancies of the ceria support [54]. In Fig. 6a, the CeO2-D sample exhibited the strongest reduction peak at temperatures below 350 °C, and the H2 consumption value (0.147 mmol·g−1) of CeO2-D in this region exceeded other samples, especially for the amorphous commercial ceria (0.018 mmol·g−1). Moreover, the high concentration of surface oxygen (Os1 + Os2) species may facilitate reducibility and oxygen mobility for the prepared samples [26]. Table 4 displayed the H2 consumption value and the corresponding Os (Os1 + Os2)/Ob ratio, and it was clear that the surface-to-bulk oxygen (Os/Ob) ratio could be affected by the morphology of the samples. It can be seen from Table 4 that CeO2-D not only owned abundant surface oxygen vacancies but also had a high content of surface oxygen, indicating that it had excellent performance and was suitable as the nickel-based catalyst carrier. As shown in Fig. 6b, four main reduction regions including α, β, γ and δ were observed in the H2-TPR curves for Ni/CeO2 samples. Meanwhile, the section ɑ comprising ɑ1 & ɑ2 peaks was ascribed to the reduction of oxygen vacancies [55,56], and it can be seen from the table that all the Ni/CeO2 catalysts consumed more H2 in this region than bare ceria, indicating that Ni2+ was incorporated into the lattice of CeO2 to form Ni-O-Ce solid solution and thus promoted the content of oxygen vacancies [34]. It was revealed from Table 5 that the H2 consumption of Ni/CeO2-D was largest at this position and exceeded nearly five times than that of Ni/CeO2-C, suggesting that the prepared catalyst possessed more abundant oxygen vacancies by using the dumbbell type support [46]. Importantly, the β region can be attributed to the reduction of NiO, which presented weak or moderate interaction with CeO2 [55]. It was obvious that the Ni/CeO2-D owned the lowest reduction temperature and H2 consumption in the β region, which might be due to the small particle size of NiO and excellent mesoporosity of Ni/CeO2-D, leading to its good reducibility accordingly [53]. Although the nickel loading amount for all samples was fixed, the H2 consumption corresponding to NiO (peak at β region) in Ni/CeO2-D dropped to the lowest value of 1.854 mmol·g−1, which was probably because the strong interaction between metal & support may form the Ni-O-Ce phase that was inaccessible for reduction. In Fig. 6b, the γ and δ regions corresponded to the ceria support reduction of surface oxygen and bulk oxygen, respectively. Compared with bare ceria, other prepared samples displayed lower reduction temperature and higher H2 consumption in γ region, while the reduction peak of surface oxygen on Ni/CeO2-C disappeared. This could be due to the fact that the nickel species exhibited high dispersity on the special morphology ceria, and thus promoted the reduction of surface oxygen as desired [41]. Notably, Ni/CeO2-D had the largest content of surface loose oxygen (active oxygen) among all the prepared samples, which can effectively react with CH x groups that generated during the reaction, and form CH x O as a result [52]. Since CH x O is considered to be a promising precursor for CO generation reported by many scholars [2], its formation and decomposition tend to greatly affect catalytic activity in DRM reaction. 3.6 TPD H2-TPD were experimentally investigated aiming at calculating the Ni dispersion and the TOF value of CH4 may be obtained from the methane conversion & Ni dispersion. It was evident from the Table 6 that Ni/CeO2-D appeared highest Ni dispersion, which was considered to be the key factor to enhance the reaction activity of Ni-based catalyst in DRM. More importantly, the TOF value of CH4 followed the sequence: Ni/CeO2-D > Ni/CeO2-B > Ni/CeO2-S > Ni/CeO2-C. This was rationally consistent with the catalytic performance of the prepared samples. At the same time, the Ni metal specific surface area was also calculated according to H2-TPD results, it was obvious that Ni/CeO2-D owned the largest value (3.10 m2·g−1). The relevant equations used for the calculation were listed in the supporting information. The surface basicity for the prepared Ni/CeO2 samples was investigated by performing the CO2-TPD experiment, and the curves were shown in Fig. 7 a. It was evident from the figure that all curves exhibited similar desorption tendency and can be divided into three desorption regions corresponding to the specific basic sites: weakly basic sites (< 300 °C), moderately basic sites (300 - 500 °C) and strongly basic sites (> 500 °C) [57]. Meanwhile the Ni/CeO2-D sample appeared the most obvious desorption peak, which had the most basic sites (0.61 mmol/g) via the quantitative analysis calculation, followed by Ni/CeO2-S (0.27 mmol/g), Ni/CeO2-B (0.22 mmol/g) and Ni/CeO2-C (only 0.11 mmol/g). The surface basic sites play a crucial role in adsorbing and activating CO2, and increasing CO2 adsorption amount will provide more surface oxygen species on the catalyst, thereby facilitate the CH x intermediates gasification from CH4 dehydrogenation. 3.7 Raman The Raman analysis was conducted to obtain oxygen vacancies information of the reduced catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the strong Raman peak at 460 cm−1 corresponded to the F2g mode of fluorite-like CeO2 phase, and the D band at range of 500 - 700 cm−1 was arisen by oxygen vacancies of the prepared catalysts [58]. The relative intensity ratio of D band to F2g band (ID/IF2g) was generally used to represent the oxygen vacancies concentration [59], and the ID/IF2g values followed the descending order: Ni/CeO2-D (0.85) > Ni/CeO2-B (0.65) > Ni/CeO2-S (0.64) > Ni/CeO2-C (0.34). This was in coincidence with the XPS results, revealing that the ceria carrier with dumbbell shape owned the largest oxygen vacancies. Compared with Ni/CeO2-C, the peak of F2g mode shifted to lower frequency when using the ceria support with special morphology, manifesting that the existence of more structural defects, which might due to the dissolution of NiO in the ceria lattice and the formation of cerium nickel solid solution [58]. 3.8 TEM Both reduced and used catalysts were characterized by TEM, and the results were depicted in Fig. 8 . It can be seen from Fig. 8 (a-d) that the reduced Ni/CeO2-D owned the smallest Ni particle size compared with other prepared samples, which might be because the unique structure with graded dumbbell shape can enhance the Ni-support interaction and prevent its particle agglomeration during calcination [60]. In Fig. 8 (e-h), the TEM images for the spent catalysts revealed that the nickel particle size of all samples grew after DRM reaction, and the spent Ni/CeO2-D did not appear any large particle clusters. Meanwhile, the average nickel particle of Ni/CeO2-D simply increased to 23.11 nm from its initial particle size of 20.53 nm after 6 h activity evaluation, suggesting a low degree of nickel sintering after reaction. Furthermore, according to the TEM-Mapping diagrams for the Ni/CeO2 samples after reduction and reaction (Fig. S6 & Fig. S7), the nickel species were dispersed on the carrier surface before and after reaction as expected. In Fig. 8 (i-l), although the filamentous carbon appeared in all the spent Ni/CeO2 samples, the position of Ni in the filamentous carbon actually affected the stability of the prepared catalysts remarkably. A few literatures [46,61] concluded that if the nickel particles existed on the top/bottom of the filamentous carbon, the active metal of the samples can still contact with the reactants effectively and maintain its catalytic active accordingly. Unfortunately, the Ni particles embedded inside the filamentous carbon would hinder the free contact between CH4/CO2 and the nickel particles and lose its activity consequently. As observed in Fig. 8i, most nickel particles in the spent Ni/CeO2-D were on both ends of the filamentous carbon, which may explain the reason for its excellent stability. In Fig. 8 (j-l), for other samples such as Ni/CeO2-C, more filamentous carbon appeared and large amount of nickel particles located inside it, which could be the main reason for their deactivation during DRM. Although the Ni sintering and carbon deposition of Ni/CeO2 samples after 6 h catalytic experiments were investigated via TEM results, we carried out XRD, TG and Raman characterizations to further explore the performances of the spent catalysts more comprehensively. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the structural properties of the spent catalysts after 6 h activity evaluation were analyzed by XRD, and all the diffraction peaks of Ni in the spent catalysts became stronger and narrower compared with the reduced samples, signifying that the Ni particle size for the as-prepared samples tended to be larger after 6 h DRM reaction. Moreover, the diffraction peak for the spent catalysts appeared at 26° could attribute to the carbon deposition, which was consistent with the reported ref. [46]. Notably in Fig. 9b, Ni/CeO2-D exhibited weaker and broader carbon peak at 26°, implying less carbon deposition occurred during DRM, which was further convinced by the TG analysis. TGA were measured to detect the amount of deposited carbon for the spent catalysts. In Fig. 9b, all the samples exhibited significant weight loss when the operation temperature exceeded 400 °C, which was largely due to the combustion of carbon deposits [51,62]. Meanwhile, the weight loss for the spent catalysts ascended in the order of Ni/CeO2-D < Ni/CeO2-S < Ni/CeO2-B < Ni/CeO2-C, proving that Ni/CeO2-D performed the least amount of deposited carbon. In order to deeply investigate the carbon deposition for the prepared samples after DRM reaction, the spent catalysts were characterized by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. S4, the peak (D band) at 1250–1400 cm−1 may be ascribed to the occurrence of the disordered amorphous carbon, and the peak (G band) within 1500–1700 cm−1 region was attributed to the deposition of graphite carbon [62]. The graphitization degree of carbon deposition in the samples was studied by calculating the ratio between G & D band intensities (IG/ID) [5], and the results revealed that Ni/CeO2-D owned the smallest IG/ID ratio, indicating its lowest graphitization degree and the existence of more activated carbon that can be eliminated easily. 4 Catalytic performance of the Ni/CeO2 samples in DRM The effect of the support morphology on the catalytic performance of the prepared samples was experimentally investigated, and the related apparent activation energies for DRM were calculated. Moreover, the effects of reaction temperature and WHSV on the catalytic activity of Ni/CeO2 were further explored to determine the optimal reaction conditions. 4.1 Effect of ceria morphology on catalytic activity The catalytic performance of the as-prepared Ni/CeO2 in DRM was measured to determine the impact of support morphology, and the results were presented in Fig. 10 . The experiments were performed at 800 °C, GHSV = 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1 and CH4:CO2 = 1:1 for 6 h. It was apparent from the figure that the catalytic activities for the Ni/CeO2 samples were highly dependent on the morphology of ceria support. On the whole, the catalytic performances obeyed the order: Ni/CeO2-D > Ni/CeO2-B > Ni/CeO2-S > Ni/CeO2-C, which was in agreement with the order of oxygen vacancies content in the as-prepared samples (Table 3). Moreover, the CH4 & CO2 conversions for Ni/CeO2-D could achieve 92% & 87%, surpassing 20% & 17% than that of Ni/CeO2-C, respectively. In Fig. 10, both reaction conversions and H2/CO for Ni/CeO2-D remained basically stable during 6 h catalytic activity experiment, while the Ni/CeO2-C sample exhibited the worst catalytic activity with 21% and 15% decrease in CH4 & CO2 conversions, respectively. Importantly, it can be concluded from the figure that Ni/CeO2-D with 3D hierarchical structure behaved the top catalytic activity and thermal stability among all the prepared catalysts, owing to its abundant oxygen vacancies that can adsorb CO2 and offer reactive oxygen species demanded for the CH4 dissociation process [46]. Meanwhile, the strong metal-support interaction, sufficient surface oxygen, small grain size and favorable basicity of Ni/CeO2-D tend to promote the catalytic activity apparently [63]. Similarly, the H2 and CO yields for all samples (Supplementary Fig. S8) also displayed the same trend during the 6 h activity evaluation. The apparent activation energy (Ea ) of methane in DRM was calculated by the Arrhenius formula: (11) ln k = − E a / R T + ln A where k denotes the rate of chemical reaction, A is the pre-exponential factor, E a is the apparent activation energy, R and T represent the gas constant and reaction temperature, respectively. In Fig. 10d, the logarithm of the reaction rate was plotted as a function of 1/T, and the activation energy could be calculated from its slope ( − E a / R ). From the figure we can concluded the activation energy order as follows: Ni/CeO2-D (88.00 kJ/mol) < Ni/CeO2-B (109.25 kJ/mol) < Ni/CeO2-S (111.14 kJ/mol) < Ni/CeO2-C (117.56 kJ /mol), which was in reasonable agreement with the order of reforming activities. Notably, when the catalyst support was ceria with special morphology, especially dumbbell-shaped, the prepared Ni/CeO2-D owned low activation energy and performed prominent catalytic activity in DRM reaction. 4.2 Effect of temperature on the catalytic activity Fig. 11 (a) illustrated the catalytic performance of the samples in DRM reaction when the reaction temperature was between 650 °C and 850 °C. Due to the endothermic feature of DRM, increasing operation temperature would lead to the promotion in the conversions and H2/CO. But when the temperature exceeded 800 °C, the growth of CH4 & CO2 conversions became slow and insignificant, and other side reactions (methane decomposition, etc.) tend to occur at much higher temperature. Meanwhile, H2/CO ration could be less than unity when the reaction temperature was far below 800 °C, which was generally caused by the occurrence of the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction along with the production of CO. Notably, the ceria is known to have high oxygen storage and transfer capacity due to its unique redox properties [64]. As reported by Huang and Yu [65], the oxygen ion conductivity could be enhanced with increasing reaction temperature, and might boost the partial migration of the lattice oxygen, resulting in the increasement of mobile reactive oxygen species and oxygen vacancies amount, thereby improving the catalytic activity accordingly [46,65]. 4.3 Effect of WHSV on the catalytic activity In Fig. 11(b), the influence of different WHSV on the catalytic activity in DRM was depicted under 800 °C and CH4:CO2 ratio of 1. Since the WHSV can directly affect the residence time of reactants for the Ni/CeO2 samples, increasing WHSV would reduce the contact time between the reactant gasses and the active sites on the prepared catalysts, arising insufficient adsorption and dissociation of CH4 & CO2, and thus depress the catalytic activity as a result [66]. Importantly, CH4 and CO2 can fully react with the catalysts as the WHSV decreased to 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1, and the enhancement effect on the conversion of reactants was negligible after the further decrease of WHSV. Hence the suitable WHSV for the Ni/CeO2 catalysts was selected as 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1 at 800 °C during DRM. 4.4 Reaction stability of Ni/CeO2-D Since the Ni/CeO2-D sample exhibited the highest catalytic activity during 6 h DRM activity evaluation (Fig. 12 ), the long-time (30 h) stability test in DRM was performed at 800 °C to further explore the thermal stability of the prepared catalyst. It can be revealed from Fig. 12 that the CH4 & CO2 conversions only declined slightly in the time range of 6 - 12 h, afterwards both conversions tended to be stable in the rest time, confirming its prominent thermal stability as expected. Moreover, the H2/CO ratio was basically maintained at 1 in 30 h, signifying that Ni/CeO2-D had an eminent inhibitory effect on side reactions such asRWGS. 5 Conclusion In this work, ceria with different morphologies were prepared by hydrothermal method and employed as nickel-based catalyst supports in DRM reaction, and a few characterizations including SEM, XRD, BET, XPS, TPR, TPD and Raman were conducted. The experimental results indicated that Ni/CeO2-D has small NiO crystal size, high Ni dispersion, good mesoporosity, abundant active oxygen and sufficient basic sites. The activity evaluation results of the prepared catalysts revealed the strong morphology dependence on the catalytic performance, and Ni/CeO2-D with 3D hierarchical structure possessed the most favorable catalytic performance. Under the optimal working conditions of 800 °C and 21,600 mL·h−1·gcat −1, both CH4 and CO2 conversions for the prepared Ni/CeO2-D could achieve 92% and 87% in DRM, respectively. This was mainly because the oxygen vacancies can adsorb CO2 and produce CO & reactive oxygen species, and also the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) was conducive to the cleavage of CH bonds. Therefore, the nickel-based catalysts supported by dumbbell-shaped CeO2 are bound to become a promising candidate in DRM reaction. coredata.dc:description: CeO2 is widely used as Ni-based catalyst support in methane dry reforming (DRM), and the hierarchical structure of the ceria behaves a favorable effect on the performance of the catalyst. Ceria with different morphologies, including dumbbell (CeO2-D), bouquet (CeO2-B) and shuttle (CeO2-S) shapes, are hydrothermally prepared, and the effect of ceria shape on the catalytic performance of Ni/CeO2 in DRM is investigated by a fixed-bed tubular reactor. The results indicate that Ni/CeO2-D demonstrates the best reaction conversions & TOF value, whose conversions of CH4 & CO2 can reach 92% & 87%, respectively. Furthermore, a series of characterization results (XPS, H2-TPR and Raman) confirm that the Ni/CeO2-D own the abundant oxygen vacancies and strong metal-support interaction, which promote the reactivity of CH4 and CO2, resulting in its most prominent catalytic performance. Additionally, Ni/CeO2-D possesses other distinct advantages due to its hierarchical dumbbell-like structure confirmed by high Ni dispersion (H2-TPD), abundant surface oxygen (H2-TPR) and sufficient basic sites (CO2-TPD).
coredata.dc:title: Morphology effect of ceria support with hierarchical structure on the catalytic performance for nickel-based catalysts in dry reforming of methane
